> > 4) The NEAT paradigm is not biased toward either of these network
> > f=
eatures.  Any node has an equal chance connecting to any other node
> > (ex=
cepting the initial connections between input and output nodes).
> 
> Which=
 would be more like the case /within/ a neural column, for example,
> which=
 contains far more neurons (approx. 100k is a figure I recall) than
> any N=
EAT evolved ANN I've ever seen. If clustering is a strategy for
> dealing w=
ith complexity, and our ANN's don't get very complex then it's
> not clear =
that it would be a useful strategy to engineer into NEAT. On
> the other ha=
nd clustering may happen at numerous levels, so e.g.a neural
> column may c=
ontain sub-clusters, some of which may contain very small
> groups similar =
in size to our ANN's.

Most of the cases mentioned in the book have numerou=
s levels of
connectivity.  Clusters, clusters of clusters, clusters of clus=
ters of
clusters, etc..  Not sure about the brain, though.

> Of course the=
 ANN's in NEAT are effectively dimensionless, any neuron
> can connect to a=
ny other without any limits or concept of relative
> distance and the lack =
of this restriction is one of the benefits we have
> over biology. Perhaps =
though clustering is not just a strategy for
> dealing with physical limita=
tions, but actually has other positive side
> effects.

One of the features=
 of cluster connectivity mentioned in the book is
that such connections are=
 sparse and largely random.  For a modular
approach to approximate this, ra=
ndom inter-module connectivity might
be necessary.

- Philip
